$$INTRO1.text:
Short instructions on how to use this file.

This is our first foray into putting Microsoft Excel files on the
CBT Tape.  We simply FTP'ed them to FB-80 pds members, in binary,
with no further changes.

I tried FTP downloading them back to a PC, and looking at them with
Microsoft Excel, after renaming them on the PC appropriately:

     julianx.xls    and    systemj.xlsx
Seems to work OK.  You'll have to try them yourself.

Questions:   Sam Golob  -  sbgolob@cbttape.org    or
                           sbgolob@attglobal.net

$$NOTE01.text:
Subject:  Julian Calendar Update
From:     rharrison@ODOT.ORG
Date:     11/28/2012 1:07 PM
To:       sbgolob@cbttape.org

Sam,
Here is a copy of the Julian Calendar that I got from the CBT website
that has changes that I made.

It has two tables on the second sheet where someone can add their
own holidays and paydays (or whatever they want to call them).
The first sheet/calendar will then highlight those days for them.

If you wish, you may distribute it as per standard CBT policy.
I would also value your opinion on my changes.

Enjoy!

Robert Harrison
Information Services Division
State of Oklahoma
Office of Management and Enterprise Services
200 NE 21st St.
Oklahoma City, OK 73105
405-521-4197

$$NOTE02.text:
Subject:  Re: Julian Calendar Update
From:     rharrison@ODOT.ORG
Date:     11/28/2012 3:55 PM
To:       "Sam Golob" <sbgolob@cbttape.org>

Hello Sam,

While you are waiting, one of the things I added was sheet 2.
When you look at it, "unhide" columns B and G.

I wanted to make the calendar easy to maintain, so I designed it
so someone would just have to add the dates for the particular
category, and the spreadsheet would take care of the rest.

Columns B and G are the dates converted to EXCEL internal number
for the date.

Columns B and C are a table, and columns G and H are another table.
They are used in a VLOOKUP in the conditional formatting on sheet 1.

I also changed the conditional formatting for the cells on sheet 1.
I will have to pull it up to tell you exactly what.

Talk to you tomorrow,

Robert.
